results.title: Nangiloc-Colignan Community Tackles Salinity
results.creator_credit: Dept of Ag and Rural Affairs and Sunraysia Horticultural Centre
results.brief_description: The Nangiloc - Colignan communtiy are working together to tackle the problem of increased salinity in the soil in the Sunraysia district. Farming and irrigation go hand in hand, and with community effort, the aim is to make sure that farming practices enrich rather tahn deplete a vital resource.

results.title: Naming the federal capital of Australia: the ceremony
results.brief_description: Newsreel footage of the ceremonies surrounding the naming of Canberra on 12 March 1913 including scenes of Capital Hill, Andrew Fisher, Billy Hughes, the Light Horse Brigade and the laying of the various foundation stones. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Naked killer (Director's cut) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Clarence Fok Yiu, Jing Wong and Wong Jing's Workshop Ltd
results.brief_description: The director’s cut, widescreen version of the film with additional footage and new subtitles. An amphetamine paced delight, this furiously edited Hong Kong film is about a group of killer female assassins who decide it is time to enact their revenge on the men who have obstructed their lives. The plot is largely preposterous but what is undeniable is the sheer pleasure taken by the film-makers in delivering a never-ending feast of action, spectacle, colour and martial arts fighting. Director Fok-Yiu is one of the talented South East Asian directors who have proven an influence on directors as diverse as Quentin Tarantino and Australia’s Geoffrey Wright. The film features a cold-blooded lesbian killer, Princess, who steals the show in a subversive feminist reworking of the karate “villain”. Though violent, the action is tongue-in-cheek. In Cantonese with English and Chinese subtitles.

results.title: Naica and the squirrel
results.creator_credit: Elisabeta Bostan and Bucuresti Film Studios
results.brief_description: The story of a little boy who leaves his parents’ farm to track a hen-stealing fox in the snow-clad forest. In an abandoned hut he befriends some squirrels. First Prize, Venice Biennial-International Exhibition of Children’s Films 1967.

results.title: Myst (MAC)
results.brief_description: You are about to be drawn into an amazing alternative reality. ‘Myst’ is a game that was designed from the ground up to draw you in with little or no distractions on the screen to interfere with the feeling of being there. It is non-linear, with the most depth, detail and reality you’ve ever experienced in a game. The key to playing the game is to lose yourself in this fantastic virtual exploration, and act and react as if you were really there.

results.title: My own yard to play in
results.brief_description: Photographed on the streets of New York, this film penetrates the world children create in their play. It shows children of varying ages and different nationalities playing in the streets regardless of the life going on around them. It stresses the need for better recreational facilities for children in large metropolitan areas, and the need of a child to have a yard of its own. Production and editing by Patricia Jaffe, Larry Silk, John Schultz and Peggy Lawson.

results.title: My little chickadee
results.brief_description: Mae West is teamed with W.C. Fields in this classic comedy filled with Wild West action and lusty humour. The familiar Westian swagger, drawl, wisecracks and innuendos are all included, likewise the typical Field’s routines and quick-triggered comments. The pairing of the two stars was at the time considered to ensure a box-office success, but it would see sparks fly with the clashing of two great super-egos. However a West-Fields non-aggression pact was inspired in part by the fact that the two players wrote their own screen story. Scenes in which the pair work together are reduced to a minimum with the script set up being a continual series of episodes, first with West and then with Fields. The story is simple; Flower Belle Lee, returning from a complete course in a Chicago dance hall, has a way with men. A masked bandit falls in love with her, which eventually leads to her being drummed out of town. Meeting Cuthbert J. Twillie on the train on the way out, she believes him to have money, and promotes a fake wedding ceremony. The pair hit the next fronteir settlement, where Twillie becomes the sherrif, and West tosses her charms around rather freely.

results.title: My Life to live
results.brief_description: Illustrates the experiences of a young college student in his search for and discovery of self-identity. Shows the importance of defining yourself and determining your own lifestyle, and the value of facing events from the past, and coming to terms with and handling feelings of personal guilt.

results.title: My first alphabet
results.creator_credit: Debney Park Secondary College, Colin Read, Gene Geoffrey and Jenny Cocks
results.brief_description: A colourful and engaging animated alphabet with an Oz flavour to it suitable for young children between the ages 3 to 6. The claymation characters were created and designed by all the students from Year 8/9 Art and Design, Debney Park Secondary College.
